The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some controversy. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all involve the assumption that quantum mechanics is a special case of a more general theory. The purpose of this paper is to show that this assumption is unnecessary.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of great interest to evolutionary biologists because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. Here, we report the results of a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and the genome of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are a sister taxon to the less reduced cnidarians, and that the extreme reduction in body plan and gene content is likely to have occurred during the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic one.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to cause disease. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our results provide a mechanism of action for SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and highlight the importance of the Nup98-Rae1 complex in the antiviral response. These findings may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies to combat the ongoing pandemic. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the Hv1 channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the impact depends on the crop’s response to temperature and the variability of temperature. We show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in most of the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries, and that this variability will increase with warming. This variability will increase the risk of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the top four maize-exporting countries, and will increase the probability of global production losses greater than 10% in any given year to 20% under 4 °C of warming. These results highlight the importance of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in savanna ecosystems. However, the extent to which species consume the same plant species is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of plant remains in the fossil record and traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and digestive physiology, these species differed in their proportional grass consumption, dietary overlap, and dietary composition. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that the diversity of large herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms of niche partitioning in large herbivore assemblages. This will be critical for the development of effective conservation strategies for this iconic group of animals.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, and many are anticipating difficulties accessing the CARES Act.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the plastic debris load on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than the 1.1 million tons estimated in a recent report. This discrepancy is due to the selective removal of plastic debris by a combination of processes, including nano-fragmentation, transference to the ocean interior, and sinking processes. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of plastic debris in the ocean and the importance of further research in this field.

The age of the Solar System is one of the most fundamental questions in astronomy. We determined the age of presolar grains, which are the seeds of the Sun, and found that they are older than the Sun. This result is important for the understanding of the formation of the Solar System.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded substantially. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could double again by midcentury, as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of sociality. Here, we show that the evolution of sociality, in the form of domestication, and the evolution of allonursing, both of which increase the amount of energy available to the mother, are associated with an increase in reproductive output. This increase is not due to an increase in resource availability, but rather an increase in metabolic power. This result has implications for the evolution of sociality in mammals and other taxa. It also has implications for the evolution of the placenta, which is the organ that provides the link between the mother and the fetus. The placenta is the organ that allows the fetus to access the mother’s metabolic resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the cerebellar cortex. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of the toxic forms of α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of this drug to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be a major step forward in the development of a treatment for this orphan disease. (Show more)

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling the contractility of the blood vessels, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells, and the cells are arranged in a highly organized manner. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network, and the network is organized in a way that is effective for both local and global communication. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are essential for understanding the pandemic and for developing effective responses. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the information they contain is not always easy to extract. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides a common interface to a wide range of data on the COVID-19 pandemic. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are useful for a wide range of applications, including epidemiological modeling, public health surveillance, and research into the social and behavioral aspects of the pandemic. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We hope that the API will be useful to researchers and practitioners in the field.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate, blood pressure, and muscle contraction. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in these channels. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the collapse of the selectivity filter on activation. Finally, we have demonstrated that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, archaea, fungi, and viruses that is thought to play a role in the health of the animal. The role of fungi in this ecosystem is less well understood, but they are known to be abundant and diverse in the gut. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, and that these natural products are produced in the gut. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be harnessed for the benefit of herbivores and humans.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with the risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and that this effect is mediated by the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is due to reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, which is a key regulator of brain energy metabolism. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This work also provides a potential mechanism for the development of social dominance hierarchies in the absence of a clear genetic hierarchy. These findings are of interest to the general scientific community and to clinicians working in the field of anxiety disorders. (Show more)

The design of mechanical structures with programmable responses is of great importance for the development of multifunctional devices. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis method to design multifunctional structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, and the synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures are heteroassembled into architectures to achieve highly complex and navigable responses. The proposed method can be extended to design multifunctional devices with specific responses for various applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of multifunctional structures and devices.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the oxygen carrying capacity of the blood. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and that it is expressed in the erythroid lineage. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal erythroid lineage and that it is necessary for the developmental silencing of adult hemoglobin expression. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that SREBP1 can be used to sensitize cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the use of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) is the most common treatment for hypertension. However, the mechanism of action of LCCBs is not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate STIM/ORAI Ca2+ channels, which are involved in the development of cardiovascular remodeling. Our findings have important implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. We show that the policy was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but did halt the decline of early-seral–associated bird populations. The NWFP is a unique case study for evaluating the influence of policy on biodiversity.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a long and costly process, which is often unsuccessful. Here, we present a rational design approach to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. We use a computational approach to predict the activity of acylide antibiotics, which are a new class of antibiotics that have been discovered recently. We show that the predicted activity of the compounds is highly correlated with their in vitro activity. We also show that the predicted compounds are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This approach can be used to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. (Show more)

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The Lake Malawi cichlid fish are a globally unique group of endemic species, which have evolved in a highly dynamic environment over the past 1.3 My. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The record shows a dramatic shift in the effective moisture regime at the MPT, which coincided with the formation of the Lake Malawi basin and the evolution of the cichlid fish. The record also shows that the climate was drier before the MPT, and that the lake level was lower, enabling the evolution of the cichlid fish to occur in a more extensive habitat. The cichlid fish are a unique example of a system that has evolved in response to large-scale changes in the hydroclimate. This study provides a unique insight into the role of hydroclimate variability in the evolution of a complex, multispecies freshwater ecosystem. (Less)
The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become ubiquitous in many countries. This study shows that this practice has important implications for sleep, performance, and health.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 100-m drop in temperature that occurred 12,900 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered this cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of the magnetic grains/microspherules are consistent with a terrestrial origin, and that the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the rare-earth-rich spherules indicate that they are from the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that bolide impacts triggered the Younger Dryas cooling. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been extensively studied, but the impact of CTLA-4 deficiency in the adult mouse has not been fully explored. Here, we show that the absence of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to the development of a variety of autoinflammatory diseases, which are not observed in congenital deficiency. These findings have implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases, as well as for the development of new therapies for the treatment of cancer.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles, including the origins of plant feeding, using a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes for 521 species. We found that the evolution of beetles and angiosperms was coevolved, and that the evolution of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes was key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles.

We first train a neural network to predict the binding affinity of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We then use the trained model to optimize the CDR sequences of the antibody. This process is repeated until the desired level of performance is achieved. The optimized antibody can then be used to develop an antibody drug candidate for the treatment of COVID-19.

We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) of technology. We find that, contrary to previous claims, population size does not enhance CCE. We also find that the relationship between population size and CCE is nonmonotonic, and that the incremental improvement in technology performance is greatest in the smallest population size. These findings have implications for the design of cultural evolution experiments and the interpretation of previous results. They also suggest that the relationship between population size and CCE may be contingent on the specific conditions under which the experiment is conducted. (Less)

APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that the amount of C1q accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration, is highly dependent on APOE alleles. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth, and its formation mechanism is still unknown. In this study, we propose a new mechanism of the inner core formation, which is based on the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron. This mechanism provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox, which has been a long-standing problem in geophysics.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are key features of marijuana abuse.
We show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can be used to understand the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a very successful approach to many problems in science and engineering. However, it is still a black box, and we do not understand why it works. In this paper, we show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that there are problems where no algorithm can find a stable solution. This is a fundamental limitation of the approach, and it is not due to the lack of universality of neural networks. Our results have implications for the design of algorithms and for the interpretation of results.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The scientific community is currently debating the role of exponential growth in the spread of the disease. The classic experiment used to study this phenomenon is a case in point. It is cited in countless scientific publications, but its design flaws are not. This article discusses the flaws of the experiment, which are not only a cautionary tale for the study of exponential growth, but also for the study of human behavior in general.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and the causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense research. In contrast, the pathogen that causes the less-studied diffuse lepromatous leprosy is poorly understood. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is the first genome sequence of a human leprosy pathogen. We also provide evidence that M. lepromatosis is not a neuropathogen.

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the Heisenberg spin chain can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a major step forward in the study of the entanglement dynamics, as it allows for a complete understanding of the entanglement evolution in the space–time scaling limit.

The development of a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 is a top priority for the global community. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. The vaccine candidate was shown to be safe and effective in a relevant animal model. This study provides a promising candidate for the development of a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2. The vaccine candidate is expected to be a valuable addition to the arsenal of vaccines against COVID-19. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) was the longest and most devastating of the four pandemics of plague. It led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated, with rodent and human ectoparasite vectors being proposed. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

The evolution of the brain is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it involves the study of the past, the inside of the skull, and the behavior of animals. Here, we use the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain size in amniotes, from the earliest tetrapods to humans. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a member of the HSP90 chaperone family that is found predominantly in mitochondria. TRAP1 is considered to be an anticancer target, but current inhibitors cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, making their utility as probes of TRAP1 function questionable. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This would have important implications for the development of TRAP1-targeted therapies. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, and they are the basis for many cellular processes, such as cell motility. Actin filaments are also the targets of the ADF/cofilin family of proteins, which are involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin binds to actin filaments and disassembles them, and we show that this disassembly is enhanced by mechanical forces. We propose that this mechanism is critical for ADF/cofilin to disassemble highly connected actin filaments in cells. This mechanism could be important for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in many cellular processes.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often consumed in excess. This study provides evidence that the consumption of fructose relative to glucose may result in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of action of sweeteners and may be relevant to the development of obesity.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island has been colonized by different waves of people, with a recent contribution of people from Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. The contribution of people from Europe and the Middle East is also recent, and it is limited to a few villages. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a valuable resource for the future studies of the island. It also provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a valuable resource for the future studies of the island.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which the emotions of others influence our own. We show that this occurs even when people are not directly interacting with the content that is influencing them. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in social networks, and for the design of social media platforms.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and the functions of many RNAs are not dependent on their sequence. However, the structure and sequence of noncoding RNAs can be modified to regulate their function. One of the most common modifications in coding regions is the pseudouridine (Ψ) modification, which is present in 10–20% of mRNAs. Here, we show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can impact protein synthesis. We find that the presence of Ψ can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can have a significant impact on the translation of mRNAs in cells. This is an important finding for understanding the function of many noncoding RNAs and the translation of mRNAs in cells. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of mammals in water. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a cooler temperature in the nasal cavity, but the underlying mechanism has not been elucidated. Here, we show that mouse airway cells, which are the primary target of rhinovirus infection in the upper respiratory tract, exhibit a more efficient antiviral defense response at 37 °C than at 33 °C. This difference in the response to rhinovirus infection at the two temperatures is exploited by rhinovirus to preferentially replicate at the cooler temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond appropriately to environmental signals. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects contact with surfaces on short timescales using the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin. This mechanism requires attachment of type IV pili to a solid surface, followed by pilus retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. Like other chemotaxis pathways, pili-mediated surface sensing results in a transient response amplified by a positive feedback that increases type IV pili activity, thereby promoting long-term surface attachment that can stimulate additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. The methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like chemosensor PilJ directly interacts with the major pilin subunit PilA. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa not only uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanism may be important for the successful colonization of the human respiratory tract by this pathogen. The importance of agricultural pesticides in surface water has been underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. This study provides a global metaanalysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water and the risk of pesticide exposure to aquatic organisms. We show that the presence of pesticides in surface water is widespread and that the risk of pesticide exposure to aquatic organisms is high. This study highlights the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread to more than 216 countries and territories, infecting millions of people and causing more than 400,000 deaths. The virus has also been detected in a variety of animal species, including white-tailed deer, which are susceptible to infection. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, the predominant cervid in North America. We also provide evidence of multiple human-to-deer and deer-to-deer transmissions, which may have contributed to the persistence of the virus in the wild. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust “One Health” approach to study the ecology, evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the livelihoods of millions of people, the food systems, the water quality, and the ecology of the rivers and the surrounding lands. This paper examines the problems and the opportunities for moving toward sustainable hydropower practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the number of affected individuals is expected to increase dramatically in the coming decades. The disease is characterized by the presence of two pathological processes, the accumulation of the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide and the formation of neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) composed of the protein tau. Here, we show that the Aβ peptide itself is a potent inflammatory agent, and that it may be the primary cause of the neuroinflammation that is observed in the earliest stages of the disease. This finding has implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD, and may also have relevance to other neurodegenerative conditions.

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is a story of a species that was first domesticated in the Near East, and then spread to Europe, where it became a key component of the agricultural economy. The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe is, however, not known. Here we present the results of a comprehensive survey of the chicken in the Southern Levant, which shows that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. This suggests that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This is an important step in the understanding of the spread of chickens in Europe and the development of the agricultural economy in the ancient world. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are important for understanding the role of the protein in the cell. Here we report the results of a detailed study of the folding of a large protein. We show that the folding of the maltose binding protein, a protein of known structure and sequence, proceeds through distinct steps. The steps are not instantaneous, and the intermediates are not random conformations. The results are important for understanding the role of the protein in the cell. They also provide a model for the study of the folding of other proteins. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, they function as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps, which are required for rapid degradation of the capped transcripts. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the Np4 cap is not the one that is inactivated by stress, but rather a different enzyme that prefers capped substrates as a source of phosphate for the formation of the nucleoside tetraphosphate cap. This enzyme has a unique mechanism for recognizing capped 5′ termini, and the position of the phosphate it attacks is determined by the structure of the RNA substrate. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, the metabolic product of arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis.

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of humans is comparable to that of all animals and plants combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, when perturbed, returns to a state of activity at a rate that is proportional to the activity of the system at the time of perturbation. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including earthquakes, avalanches, and sandpiles. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified to improve performance. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. This opens up new possibilities for tailoring the properties of diamond, which can be used in a variety of applications.

The discovery of the antimicrobial activity of NCR peptides in the nodules of Medicago truncatula led to the identification of a large number of NCR peptides in the genome of this model legume. However, there is a lack of knowledge regarding the structural architecture, antifungal activity, and modes of action of these peptides against plant fungal pathogens. Here, we report the structure of one of the NCR peptides, NCR044, and demonstrate its potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide binds to phosphoinositides and penetrates fungal cells, causing cell death. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This would be a significant contribution to the control of plant fungal diseases. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely that the female reproductive tract makes contributions to the life history of sperm. However, the extent of such contributions is largely unknown. Here, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the female reproductive tract makes substantial contributions to the sperm proteome, and we identify a number of female-derived proteins that are likely to support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the adhesion of platelets to the vessel wall. In some people, mutations in VWF cause a bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We have developed a method to measure the force dependence of the binding of VWF to platelets, which is important for the formation of the platelet plug during bleeding. We find that the binding of VWF to platelets is force dependent, and that this force dependence can be explained by conformational changes in the protein. These changes are triggered by alterations in flow during bleeding. The results provide a mechanism for the pathophysiology of VWD. The method can be used to study other proteins and may be useful in the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the study of viruses in the human microbiome, and the results are used to identify previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results are expected to be of interest to researchers in the fields of virology, immunology, and human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI community.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has been inferred from isotopic records, but the temperature of the surface of the Earth has also been inferred from the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. We here present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth at the time of the divergence of an organism, which is shown to be consistent with the temperature inferred from the isotopic record. This method provides a new way to determine the temperature history of the Earth and to test the validity of the temperature history inferred from isotopic records.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. The activation gate of K+ channels is a critical element for channel opening and the inactivation gate for channel closing. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels can show slow C-type inactivation and that the rates of C-type inactivation and recovery are inversely correlated with the extent of C-type inactivation. We propose that BK channel C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings may help to understand the BK channel’s unique properties and may provide a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channels. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The Plasmodium parasite invades the human red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC, altering the biophysical properties of the cell. This change in the RBC’s biophysical properties is required for invasion and is likely to be a critical energy barrier to overcome. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is a promising material for the next generation of devices, but its properties can be modified to improve performance. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the bandgap can be completely closed, without phonon instability. This opens up new possibilities for tailoring the properties of diamond, which can be used in a variety of applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus infection. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a left-corner parser, starting with the simplest possible syntactic constituents and gradually adding more complex ones. Here, we provide evidence for this parser in the human brain. We show that the brain encodes the merge operation, which combines two words into a syntactic constituent, and that this operation is applied repeatedly to build syntactic structures. We also show that the merge operation is implemented in the brain in a way that is consistent with a left-corner parser. Our results provide neurophysiological evidence for the existence of a left-corner parser and suggest that it is implemented in the brain. This is important for understanding the nature of language and the brain.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in the development of the nervous system and the immune system. Axin is also a substrate for the ubiquitin ligase complex that degrades the transcription factor β-catenin. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the two forms of Axin. This differential responsiveness may be used in tissue-specific regulation of redundant genes.

This study provides a detailed characterization of the brain circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this effect is blocked by lesions of dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and by dopamine receptor antagonists. Finally, we show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it may be a primary target for pharmacotherapies for obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil is a key trait for plants. However, the nitrogenase enzyme, which is essential for nitrogen fixation, is highly sensitive to oxygen and is therefore not active in the soil. This limits the ability of plants to fix nitrogen in the soil, and thus to increase their nitrogen use efficiency. Here, we demonstrate a method to control the nitrogenase enzyme in bacteria, which are the primary nitrogen-fixing organisms in the soil, and thus to control the ability of plants to fix nitrogen in the soil. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for controlling the nitrogen-fixing activity of bacteria. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the small number of communities that participated in the program. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management, but the results are not conclusive.

Hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the bodies of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein is the target for the majority of vaccines against COVID-19. However, the current vaccines are based on the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence, which is not fully compatible with the RBD of the variants of concern. Here, we report the design and synthesis of an engineered RBD that is fully compatible with the variants of concern and is expected to provide better protection against the variants. The engineered RBD can be expressed on a virus-like particle, which can be used as a vaccine platform. This engineered RBD can be used in the development of vaccines against other coronaviruses. This work provides a potential solution to the global access issue of COVID-19 vaccines. (Show more)

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of infancy. Despite intensive treatment, the prognosis of patients is poor. In recent years, we have learned that neuroblastoma is a heterogeneous disease, and that different molecular subtypes exist. In this study, we show that the ALK receptor is involved in the development of neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in the history of medicine. This study provides a comprehensive view of the evolution of Y. pestis during the formative period of its emergence, from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age. We show that the emergence of Y. pestis as a human pathogen was a long and complex process, and that the pathogen underwent a series of evolutionary steps before it became a deadly disease. We also reveal the presence of a flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Iberia, which is not found in other regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. These data provide a unique view of the formative years of plague and its early evolution. (Less)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

The management of agricultural systems can influence the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on a Midwestern Mollisol can be optimized to increase the amount of C stored in the soil. This optimization is achieved by minimizing soil disturbance, diversifying crop rotations, and adding manure. These practices can increase the amount of C stored in the soil by 18 to 29% over 29 y of management. This study highlights the importance of grasslands in the storage of C in the soil and the potential of rotational grazing to increase the amount of C stored in the soil. These results have implications for the management of agricultural systems to mitigate climate change. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We have developed a framework to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be used to inform research and public health interventions to prevent and control future outbreaks.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of this reward is often an important factor in the success of pollination, as it serves as a visual cue for pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red flower of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify this compound in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae, suggesting that this trait is convergent in two different vertebrate-pollinated species. This work provides evidence for the importance of this trait in the evolution of pollination and suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. (Show more)

We present a case study of the genetic landscape of a single village in Bavaria, Germany, during the Early Medieval period. We show that the genetic ancestry of the men in the village is very similar to that of the modern population of Bavaria, while the women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. We also show that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The study also highlights the importance of vector-borne pathogens, zoonotic pathogens, and emerging pathogens in the region. The study also demonstrates the importance of coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. The lagging strand template is replicated by the pol δ polymerase, which requires the PCNA sliding clamp for processivity and stability. Here, we report the results of a series of kinetic studies that provide a detailed picture of the association of pol δ with PCNA. We show that the pol δ holoenzyme is not stable on undamaged DNA and that the association with PCNA is loose while replicating the lagging strand. These results have implications for the synthesis of Okazaki fragments in humans and the repair of DNA lesions. They also highlight the importance of the structure of the pol δ holoenzyme in the regulation of its processivity and stability.

The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which is able to synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The polymerase ribozyme is able to synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the in vitro reconstruction of the RNA world and the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, reduce mortality, and shorten the hospital stay. The results provide a reference for the clinical treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-derived metabolites suggests that these fungi have evolved mechanisms to balance the beneficial and detrimental effects of copper. This study demonstrates that the xan BGC is involved in copper homeostasis and that the xan BGC is present in several filamentous fungi. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study also provides evidence that the xan BGC is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This knowledge may be useful in the development of antifungal and antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

Silica is a major component of the Martian surface, and its origin and evolution are important to understanding the planet. Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is the first evidence for this polymorph on another planet. The sedimentary rock is cogenetic with other crystalline minerals, indicating that it formed at the same time as the other minerals. The sedimentary rock is also a source of the crystalline minerals, indicating that the sedimentary rocks were a source of material for the silicic volcanism.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of agricultural and forestry systems, and the frequency of late-spring frosts (LSFs) is increasing in many regions. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is linked to the evolutionary history of the species involved, and that this distribution is changing in response to climate change. Our findings have implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of these diseases is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells and that this process requires the expression of both the transcription factor T-bet and the cytokine IL-12. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is also driven by the actions of other cells, including astrocytes. We have developed a method to rapidly produce induced astrocytes from living ALS patients, which can be used to study the disease process and identify potential therapies. This method will enable the study of the disease in a living patient, and the identification of potential therapies in a living patient, in a way that is not possible with current disease models. This will greatly accelerate the development of therapies for ALS. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the tick. We demonstrate that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the gut microbiota of their vector to enhance transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the evolution of birds, as it is the last major change in the evolution of the avian bauplan. The discovery of a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail. The discovery of this new group of birds also highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of mosaic traits.

The climate system is a coupled system, and the climate response to a change in forcing depends on the nature of the coupling. In this paper, we show that the coupling between the troposphere and the stratosphere is such that the response of the stratosphere to a change in tropospheric forcing is delayed, and that this delay can have a significant impact on the climate response.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we describe a new mechanism of color polymorphism, which is based on the presence of a specific protein in the animal. This protein binds biliverdin, the pigment of the red color, and is responsible for the green color of the animal. This mechanism is present in anurans, and it has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and the hypoxic tumor microenvironment is a key determinant of the phenotype of cancer cells. Here, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is dependent on ALKBH5 and HIF-1α and -2α, and NANOG-expressing cells are enriched in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for cancer treatment.

The use of fetal animal skins in the production of parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the future, and to assess the authenticity of manuscripts. (Less)

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. We report precise ages for five volcanic ash beds, which define a precise age model for the extinction and recovery. The age model reveals that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction and recovery, suggesting that the trigger and kill hypotheses are unlikely to be the primary causes of the extinction. The age model will be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill hypotheses, and for evaluating the role of rate-dependent processes in the extinction and recovery. (Abridged)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the orphan nuclear receptor superfamily, which is involved in various biological processes, such as cancer, metabolism, and circadian rhythm. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and is the main target for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies. The D614G mutation is the most common mutation in the spike protein of circulating SARS-CoV-2 viruses. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the spike with the mutation is more open and may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results may help to inform the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.
