The chemical properties of atoms are central to chemistry, and they are also the basis of many chemical models. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a first step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can have significant impacts on the global carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of these impacts is uncertain, and the relative importance of climate and human drivers of fire activity is unclear. We show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of the symbionts of the light-producing squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, and that the catabolism of the glycan is required for the acidification of the symbiotic organ that enhances the activity of the symbionts. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more general feature of animal-microbe interactions than previously thought. This may be particularly important for the maintenance of mutualisms in the face of environmental change. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show how to represent documents as topic sequences, and how to identify the topics that are present in a corpus. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives of violent deaths, and show that many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We also provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to a wide range of domains, and can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics, and to study the gendered nature of topics in text data.

The Black Death, which killed an estimated 30–50% of the European population in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating events in human history. The origin of this disease is still debated, but the most widely accepted hypothesis is that it was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, for centuries before the arrival of the disease in Europe. This suggests that the Black Death was not the result of a single introduction of the bacterium, but rather of multiple introductions, which occurred in response to climate fluctuations in Asia. Our results provide evidence for a complex interplay between climate and the spread of plague in medieval Europe. (Abridged full text)

Asteroids are a keystone species in marine ecosystems, and their loss has been shown to have cascading effects on the structure and function of the ecosystem. Here, we provide evidence that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the mass mortality of sea stars (asteroids) on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus causing a mass mortality of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge, and there is an urgent need for the development of new therapies for AML. Here, we show that an antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is effective in the treatment of AML. This antibody is capable of both antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling, which is important for the growth of AML cells. These results provide evidence that IL1RAP can be targeted with an antibody capable of achieving both modes of action, and they provide a potential strategy for the treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other cancers as well. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island has been colonized by different waves of people, with a recent contribution of people from Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. The contribution of people from Europe and the Middle East is also recent, and it is limited to a few villages. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, and it is a valuable resource for the future studies of the island.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. The protein also interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. These results demonstrate that the protein and RNA compete for the same binding sites on the same target gene. This is an example of a protein that has evolved to interfere with the ability of an sRNA to regulate its target genes. This is an example of a protein that has evolved to interfere with the ability of an sRNA to regulate its target genes.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines and treatments. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to improve the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-SeekBar: This figure shows the workflow of our deep learning approach. We first train a neural network to predict the binding affinity of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We then use the trained model to optimize the CDR sequences of the antibody. The optimized antibody is then tested in the laboratory to determine its binding affinity and neutralizing activity. The results are then used to train the neural network to improve its performance. This process is repeated until the desired level of performance is achieved. The optimized antibody can then be used to develop an antibody drug candidate for the treatment of COVID-19.

Crop expert surveys are a key source of information on crop status, but are often ignored in favor of more sophisticated models and remote sensing. We show that the information contained in crop expert assessments can be used to develop a continuous, probabilistic measure of crop status that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that this measure can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert surveys are a valuable source of information that can be used to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the impact of climate change on agricultural production.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This mechanism is not reliant on persistent activity, excitatory feedback, or synaptic plasticity for storage. Instead, information is maintained in adaptive conductances that reduce firing rates and can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of the plant lineage. It is also a model system for the study of the evolution of the genome under different environmental conditions. Here, we show that the evolution of the plastid genome is linked to the evolution of the host–parasite relationship. We demonstrate that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle leads to a relaxation of selection on the plastid genome, which is accompanied by a stepwise reduction in the rate of molecular evolution. Our findings have implications for the study of the evolution of the genome in the context of the host–parasite relationship. They also have implications for the study of the evolution of the genome in the context of the evolution of the plant lineage. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the Trinity test, provides a unique link between the laboratory synthesis of quasicrystals and the history of the 20th century.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and the light-harvesting pigments, bacteriochlorophyll and bacteriopheophytin, are essential for this process. The biosynthesis of these pigments is highly conserved across all organisms that use them, and the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the chromophore, is the most important reaction in this pathway. The biosynthesis of this ring is highly conserved across all organisms that use these pigments, and the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the chromophore, is the most important reaction in this pathway.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS) and experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the development of neuroinflammation in EAE. We also found that ASK1 is involved in the development of neuroinflammation in EAE, and ASK1 is required for the development of neuroinflammation in microglia and astrocytes. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a potential therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new therapies for EAE and other neuroinflammatory diseases. The 2012–2014 drought in California is one of the most extreme droughts in the state’s history. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to anthropogenic warming. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions, which have created acute human and ecosystem impacts.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a broad phenotypic spectrum. The identification of the causal genes and the causal pathways is a major challenge in autism research. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a framework for the identification of the causal genes and the causal pathways in autism. It also provides a potential target for the development of a behavioral approach to autism research. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. They also highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare, multisystemic disorder that was first described in 2014. The syndrome is characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the Ca2+ sensor STIM1, which are associated with Stormorken syndrome, result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel in vitro and spontaneous bleeding in zebrafish embryos. These findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates and the subsequent accumulation of aggregates within other neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates is non–cell-autonomous and that the release of aggregates is required for the spread of aggregates. These results provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Bats are the only mammals that are capable of flying, and they are the only mammals that have evolved the unique ability to live in caves. The immune system of bats is very different from that of other mammals, and the immune system of bats is also very different from that of humans. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the role of LTA4H in the immune system of mammals. Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon units are essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon unit-generating enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and show that it blocks tumor growth in a mouse model of colon cancer. We also show that the one-carbon unit donor, formate, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. This effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results provide a rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer, and for the development of drugs that can selectively inhibit SHMT in cancer cells, but not normal cells. This would be a significant advance in the development of cancer therapeutics. Read less

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the cell, and thus prone to aggregation, is a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases. Here, we show that the proteins that are colocalized with mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS in inclusion bodies are also supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other human tissues. This suggests that the presence of these proteins in inclusion bodies is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons, and not merely a reflection of the presence of the same proteins in the cell. This observation may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for ALS. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal system is predicted to produce exotic quantum phenomena, including suppressed spontaneous emission, atom–light interaction anisotropy, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions. The photonic crystal system is fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. The photonic crystal system can be deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for exploring the physics of quantum many-body systems, including the study of topological phases of matter, the dynamics of quantum phase transitions, and the emergence of quantum matter with emergent symmetries. The photonic crystal system is also a promising platform for quantum engineering and quantum simulation.

The Cretaceous is a key time in the evolution of plants, and the study of the earliest plants is of great importance. Montsechia is a plant that was first discovered in the 1910s and has been poorly understood. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 specimens, the morphology and anatomy of Montsechia are presented, and it is shown to be an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and thus sister to the eudicots. This opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral DNA in the archaeological record. Here we present the first ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences, which are phylogenetically related to the most recent common ancestor of all B19V. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the recombination event that formed the third B19V genotype occurred at a time when humans were expanding into new environments. These findings are important for our understanding of the evolution of viruses and the history of humans. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and this rise is accelerating. These observations are consistent with the findings of the IPCC AR5, which projects that global mean sea level could rise 0.18–0.59 m by 2100. The rate of acceleration is not well known, however, and this, along with the uncertainty in the rate of global mean sea level rise, is a major source of uncertainty in the projections of future sea level.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has increased with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this increase has been more pronounced for those born after 1950. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 may be one explanation for this trend.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a critical component of the mechanistic picture of an enzyme reaction. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This structure is used to understand the fate of the leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The detailed picture of structure and reactivity that emerges from this work highlights the role of the crystallographic waters in the active site and the role of the cofactor in the reaction pathway. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity in an enzyme active site. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease highlights the need for the development of effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral replication, is effective in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of animal-microbe interactions. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent symbiont. We also show that the provision of this glycan is timed to occur at night, when the squid is producing light. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients to symbiotic microbes may be a general feature of animal-microbe interactions. This may be achieved by animals through the regulation of the activities of the epithelium-associated microbes in their tissues. (Show more)

This paper reports on a series of experiments and a field trial that tested the impact of a brief, online intervention on teachers’ mindsets about discipline. The intervention was designed to be scalable and to be implemented in a wide range of settings. The results suggest that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. This has important implications for the suspension crisis in schools, as well as for the quality of teacher–student relationships and student outcomes more generally.

Alkylated DNA lesions, induced by both exogenous chemical agents and endogenous metabolites, are the major cause of DNA damage and mutagenesis in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of DNA damage-induced diseases.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. This study provides robust evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can lead to a proportional increase in sales. This has the potential to have a significant impact on the health of the population and the health of the environment. The study also provides evidence that the impact of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals is not limited to the cafeteria in which the change is made, and that the impact is felt disproportionately by those who are least likely to have access to vegetarian options at home. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote more sustainable diets.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic and important interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we use a combination of quantitative proteomics and glycoproteomics to study the surfaceome of a cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes in cancer. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We also find that oncogenes have a strong impact on the glycoproteome, and that this impact is dependent on the oncogene. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a resource for the breast cancer community and beyond. The data are available at ProteomeXchange with identifier PXD014995. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its spread and severity is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the spread of this virus and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can lead to a variety of diseases, including cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this disease are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF, acting on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) expressed in cortical astrocytes, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, which leads to an up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapies for this potentially life-threatening condition. The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from the past. But what if the past is incomplete? What if we have only a small sample of the past? What if we have a very large number of samples of the past? In this paper, we describe a new way of thinking about these problems. We call it “selective inference” and we show how it can be used to make better inferences in these situations. We illustrate the new way of thinking with three examples: forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of vascular networks. However, the development of ECs has been difficult to achieve in vitro. Here, we report the development of endothelial cells (ECs) from human fibroblasts using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). This study provides a new approach for the development of ECs and the formation of vascular networks. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of organs. Furthermore, this approach may be useful for the development of a pluripotent stem cell-derived ECs. This study may also provide a new approach for the development of ECs from other types of cells. (Show more)

The identification of the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) RTKs as “orphan” receptors has led to the discovery of two physiological ligands, ALKAL1 and ALKAL2, and the identification of their roles in the development of the human immune system. Here, we show that the zebrafish genome contains three genes that encode augmentor ligands for Alk and Ltk. We demonstrate that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophores, the pigment cells that color the eyes and skin. These results establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for the study of the role of augmentor ligands in the development of other tissues in vertebrates. It also provides a model system for the study of the role of augmentor ligands in the development of other tissues in invertebrates.

In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function, and its deficiency causes glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS. We also found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study also provides a potential target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most pathogenic human viruses, and their genome is segmented into eight fragments. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in viral replication, and the existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. Disruption of this interaction nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. This interaction is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, suggesting that genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses might be limited. Our results provide insights into the molecular details of the selective packaging mechanism of influenza A virus. (Show more)

The development of atherosclerosis is a complex process that involves a variety of cellular and molecular events. The role of YAP/TAZ in mediating the atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been previously investigated. In this study, we demonstrate that YAP/TAZ are activated by disturbed flow in the endothelium and that this activation is required for the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation. In addition, we show that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that people have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that human-started wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel, sTRP1, as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, which is absent in the orthologs of insects. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and also a potential target of scorpion venom. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with a variety of neurological complications, including microcephaly and Guillain–Barré syndrome. The mechanisms of these complications are not fully understood, but the dynamics of the virus within the host may be important. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We find that the virus grows rapidly within the host, and that the time to detectable virus in the blood is short. We also find that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. Finally, we show that an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication can be effective in reducing the time to undetectable plasma viral load. However, the timing of the treatment is important, as treatment given too late is mostly ineffective. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are also among the most threatened ecosystems. Coral bleaching is the most common and severe form of coral mortality, but the underlying causes are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from uptake to release of nutrients by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the functional breakdown of the symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This may have implications for our understanding of the stability of other symbiotic systems in nature. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the environment. It is also the organ that is most affected by cancer. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment leads to a dysregulation of the microbiome, which in turn triggers a regenerative response that promotes tumor growth. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in cancer and cancer therapy. This work may also have implications for other epithelial tissues, such as the lung and the colon. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for patients with breast cancer, and the response to chemotherapy is a major determinant of survival. In this study, we show that the expression of the ROR1 receptor is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression is associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). We also show that the expression of ROR1 is associated with the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab, in combination with chemotherapy, is more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which is thought to have led to a weakening of the Southern Hemisphere monsoons and a drying of the continent. However, this explanation is not supported by a unique, synchronous, and widespread change in climate conditions in the Southern Hemisphere. Here, we show that a series of massive volcanic eruptions at the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a likely trigger for the changes in climate conditions.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions of low food security. Our analysis highlights the need to protect the remaining biodiversity of rivers and lakes, as well as to improve the sustainability of inland fisheries.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a potential solution. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable character of the material is the key to achieve high energy density and safety. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work also provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a platform for the discovery of novel factors that regulate the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the evolution of genomes and the diversity of life. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination activity in a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that in yeast and mice. We find that the distribution of recombination activity in plants is similar to that in animals, suggesting that the process of recombination has been conserved in eukaryotes.

The resting brain is a complex system, in which the activity of a large number of functionally related regions is coordinated. The present study provides a method for identifying and quantifying the organization of this system, which is of fundamental importance for understanding the function of the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and is essential for the translation of most mRNAs. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA. We show that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast, and that it is produced cotranscriptionally. This discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes raises the possibility that it could modulate mRNA stability and translation.

Metabolic memory is the phenomenon of prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the study of metabolic memory. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia, and in vitro, high glucose induced similar persistent hypomethylation at thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP) in cultured THP1 monocytes. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and the current standard of care is limited. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder, which is characterized by a variety of symptoms and behaviors. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with the presence of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

Tomato fruit are among the most popular fruits in the world, and the quality of the fruit is a major factor in their acceptance. The flavor of tomato fruit is largely determined by the composition of the volatile organic compounds, which are produced during ripening. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a unique flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most pervasive and profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most pervasive and profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in navigation and memory. It is also the site of a complex map of local space, which is thought to be represented by grid cells, head-direction cells, border cells, and object-vector cells. Here, we present a detailed analysis of the topographic organization of these cell types in the superficial layers of MEC, using a portable two-photon microscope. Our results suggest that grid cells are not mixed with other cell types, but are strongly coupled among themselves. This study provides a detailed view of the organization of the local-space map in MEC, which will be useful for understanding the function of this structure. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates the importance of FTs in flowering regulation and the importance of the host plant in flowering regulation of the parasite.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized specialized subsystem of the dopamine system, the striosome–dendron bouquet, which is likely to be affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Within the bouquet, striosomal fibers are tightly intertwined with dopamine-containing dendrites and also with a variety of other cell types and processes. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this paper, we show that the speed at which we respond to others is a signal of how connected we feel to them. This signal is used by others to assess the quality of our connections, and it is used by us to assess the quality of our own connections. This is a fundamental way that we understand and are understood by others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells, which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. SAN cells are characterized by the presence of Ca2+ release units, which are the sites of Ca2+ release, and a unique mechanism of Ca2+ entry, which is unique to SAN cells. We report here that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a regulator of Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, is expressed in SAN cells and plays a key role in the regulation of Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and automaticity of the SAN. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms that underlie the generation of the heart rate. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its function in plant physiology has been debated. In this study, we show that Si accumulation in rice plants increases resistance to the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. These results suggest that Si may have a role in plant defense against insects, and that the interaction between Si and JA may be an important mechanism for the regulation of plant defense. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and it is widely assumed that it is the result of a unique combination of genetic and environmental factors. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the activity of single neurons. We show that the activity of a small number of neurons can be used to represent and integrate information about the structure of language. This is achieved through a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of a small number of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic compounds or to seek out nutrients. Thus, they are dependent on the delivery of biomolecules to the cell for survival. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of biomolecules to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important for the internalization and gene silencing efficiencies. This work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step toward the development of a new class of plant therapeutics.

Nutrient inputs to coastal ecosystems are often dominated by a small number of large tributaries. However, the role of smaller tributaries in coastal eutrophication has been overlooked. We show that the majority of nutrient inputs to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan, are delivered by small tributaries. These inputs are dominated by dissolved inorganic nutrients, which are more bioavailable to algae, and are concentrated in the nearshore zone. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is driven by a random force, and we show that the same mechanism is at work in our system.

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the effects of an antibody against the NMDA receptor on the brain’s electrical activity. The results suggest that the antibody can change the dynamics of the brain, making it more susceptible to paroxysmal events. This may be a general mechanism of action for antibodies that affect the brain’s electrical activity. The study also provides a framework for understanding the effects of other drugs that affect the brain’s electrical activity. This framework may be useful for understanding the effects of other drugs that affect the brain’s electrical activity.

The Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction and the associated global warming event are among the most dramatic events in Earth history. The timing of the extinction and the extent of global warming are still debated. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate the timing and extent of the warming event. We show that the warming event was accompanied by a C and U isotope perturbation, which can be linked to an organic matter–derived C pulse. Modeling indicates that the warming event was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. The warming event was likely a key driver of the extinction.

Certification of palm oil production is a key tool for meeting corporate commitments to reduce deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. We show that certification is associated with a reduction in deforestation, but that most certified areas still contained substantial forest cover at the time of certification. Our results suggest that certification is not yet having a large impact on deforestation, but that it is having a positive impact on the sustainability of palm oil production.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the secretion of proteins and vesicles from the plasma membrane. The exocyst complex is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Here, we report the discovery of a small molecule that inhibits the exocyst complex and provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex in plants and humans. This study also offers a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at that locus. In species with multiple sex determination loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at multiple loci. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination loci on the secondary sexual characteristics of a single species, finding that multiple sex determination loci can produce a modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics. This modular variation can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by both vitamin A and iron. In this study, we show that iron, in the form of the chelator deferiprone, can reduce the levels of a toxic metabolite in the retina. This effect was demonstrated in two mouse models, one with a deficiency in the Fe export proteins hephaestin and ceruloplasmin, which leads to accumulation of Fe in the retina, and one with a deficiency in the vitamin A export protein ABCA4, which leads to accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts in the retina. These results suggest that the retina may be a unique organ that can utilize iron to reduce the toxicity of vitamin A aldehyde adducts. This study also demonstrates the utility of the mouse retina as a model for studying the effects of iron and vitamin A on the retina. (Show more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. However, the evolution of specialization in predators has been considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved a modular specialization in their feeding strategy, and that this specialization is linked to the evolution of the morphology and evolution of their tentacles. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of specialization in predators, and the mechanisms that drive the diversification of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. This is due in part to the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human behavior. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and one-carbon units are essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon unit-generating enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and show that it blocks tumor growth in a mouse model of colon cancer. We also show that the one-carbon unit donor, formate, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. This effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), a cancer with a unique dependence upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results provide a rationale for the development of SHMT inhibitors as a therapeutic strategy for DLBCL. This study provides evidence of the impact of deforestation on people’s diets in rural Tanzania. The results show that deforestation has a negative impact on people’s diets, which is likely to be due to a reduction in fruit and vegetable consumption. The results also show that forest fragmentation has a positive impact on people’s diets, which is likely to be due to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, which has increased food production by 200% over the last 60 y. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the paradox of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction, including the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, is a result of the same phenomenon.
